FeedItems.Title: Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:

The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Merge branch 'main' into dev" (#9131) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "[A11y]Incorrect Aria attribute used on label" (#9134) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
URL:'
https://www.nuget.org/users/account/ForgotPassword
https://www.nuget.org/users/account/SignUp

The aria-required property is not allowed on html label elements.
Let's either find the correct property for label elements, or move the aria-required property to the text entry box.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y]iFrame is not able to be tab navigated" (#9133) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
As part of an effort to fix tab ordering, we added a "tab-index=-1" property to the reCAPTCHA iframe.
This had the consequence of removing the entire content in the iframe from the tab order.
Changing this to tab-index=1 should enable a sensible tab order AND leave the iframe content in a tabbable state.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[A11y]Contrast of links on README tables is sometimes not high enough." (#9132) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11051729/171963165-f0f76f41-fed8-4d59-8490-1524165301fd.png)
Colour contrast of the Fancy Zones link is not high enough.
This is due to the table rendering with a non white background colour.

This will likely be an issue on all README pages that have links in tables.
Globally darkening our link colour should address this.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Details about Problem When uploading a package to nuget.org manually via the website, I can set a documentation URL that points to a readme file on github, as shown here: https://www.nuget.org/packages/blazor-server-githubactions-demo/  How do I this via a .csproject file, as I use CI / CD to publish my packages and so I don't want this to be a manual step. how publish readme file automatically along with pacakge." (#9124) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

[NuGet.org Bug]: Details about Problem When uploading a package to nuget.org manually via the website, I can set a documentation URL that points to a readme file on github,


 as shown here: https://www.nuget.org/packages/blazor-server-githubactions-demo/  

How do I this via a .csproject file, as I use CI / CD to publish my packages and so I don't want this to be a manual step. how publish readme file automatically along with pacakge.

### Repro Steps

https://www.nuget.org/packages/blazor-server-githubactions-demo/ 

### Expected Behavior

How do I this via a .csproject file, as I use CI / CD to publish my packages and so I don't want this to be a manual step. how publish readme file automatically along with pacakge.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Mark backup folders as private" (#9129) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: They are already set as private in Blob Storage. There is no known scenario that needs public (unauthenticated) access to these blobs.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Mark backup folders as private" (#9129) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: They are already set as private in Blob Storage. There is no known scenario that needs public (unauthenticated) access to these blobs.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Proposal of consolidating user wide NuGet.Config files on Linux/Mac" (#11856) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "How to include nuget lib's dll.config into my project's output binary folder?" (#11841) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have an SDK style C# project "HelloWorld" whose .csproj is like below
```XML
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net472</TargetFramework>
    <LangVersion>8</LangVersion>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="ABCLibrary" Version="1.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```
The `ABCLibrary` files in my local nuget cache are under
`C:\Users\MyUsername\.nuget\packages\abclibrary.retail-amd64\1.0.0\lib\net472` and have such files:
- ABCLibrary.dll
- ABCLibrary.dll.config

When I build my project "HelloWorld", the output binary folder only has `ABCLibrary.dll` but no `ABCLibrary.dll.config`. But the dll depends on some settings in the config so I get exceptions.

An optional solution is to add the following in my "HelloWorld.csproj":

```
<ItemGroup>
  <None Include="$(NuGetPackageRoot)\abclibrary.retail-amd64\1.0.0\lib\$(TargetFramework)\ABCLibrary.dll.config">
	<CopyToOutputDirectory>Always</CopyToOutputDirectory>
  </None>
</ItemGroup>
```

But it's too ugly and troublesome. Is there a better way to include `ABCLibrary.dll.config` into the binary folder?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: nuget.exe command line keeps prompting for username/password" (#11852) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

NuGet Version: 6.1.0.106

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

I am trying to use NuGet packages with a pre-existing nightly build system, so I need to automatically check for missing / out of date NuGet package and update them if needed.

So far I've created a Visual Studio 2019 project which has a dependency for a NuGet package that exists inside my JFrog Artifactory repo online.

If I run the command `nuget restore demopack3.sln` in command prompt on my VS2019 solution file (.sln) it prompts me for my artifactory userName / password.

After I input my info, it correctly downloads the NuGet package. And I can run the command / delete my nuget package multiple times without being prompted for my username/password again. But occasionally, seemingly at random, it prompts me for my username/password manual entry

this is a problem because I need my `nuget restore` and `msbuild` commands to be ran automatically and without user input.

is there any way I can set my Artifactory username/password inside Windows Credentials Manager or some other automated way to avoid needing to manually enter my username/password when downloading NuGet packages from an Artifactory repo?

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: NuGet 6.2 incompatible with lock file from NuGet 6.1 - NU1101: Unable to find package" (#11851) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe

### Product Version

NuGet 6.2

### Worked before?

NuGet 6.1

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Consider this csproj:

``` xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
	<PropertyGroup>
		<TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
		<RestorePackagesWithLockFile>true</RestorePackagesWithLockFile>
	</PropertyGroup>
	<ItemGroup>
		<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.CrmSdk.Data" Version="9.0.2.33" />
	</ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

1. Restore project with NuGet 6.1 `nuget.exe restore repro.csproj`. The lock file is:
``` json
{
  "version": 1,
  "dependencies": {
    "net6.0": {
      "Microsoft.CrmSdk.Data": {
        "type": "Direct",
        "requested": "[9.0.2.33, )",
        "resolved": "9.0.2.33",
        "contentHash": "gREfQl0/mh22+eV9h8PhCnAwNY5SJswLnUPxvxJwF6L2mhj5pMFMUSvlVke3Gpk94XCrBEyIgHJzFKDiMtA1aw=="
      }
    }
  }
}
```

3. Delete the obj\ directory. Restore project with NuGet 6.2. Receive error:
> NU1101: Unable to find package Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages, nuget.org

Workaround - delete the lock file. The new lock file is:

``` json
{
  "version": 1,
  "dependencies": {
    "net6.0": {
      "Microsoft.CrmSdk.Data": {
        "type": "Direct",
        "requested": "[9.0.2.33, )",
        "resolved": "9.0.2.33",
        "contentHash": "gREfQl0/mh22+eV9h8PhCnAwNY5SJswLnUPxvxJwF6L2mhj5pMFMUSvlVke3Gpk94XCrBEyIgHJzFKDiMtA1aw==",
        "dependencies": {
          "Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies": "9.0.2"
        }
      },
      "Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies": {
        "type": "Transitive",
        "resolved": "9.0.2.1",
        "contentHash": "68WUDm0RFg9RjrkxU8cTqc+bRsKa55YkG2SM81rNVMFUtNL56FlGW5gifoaABbR7KU15+myXTA/a+Vqbqc6vQQ=="
      }
    }
  }
}
```

Note the additional dependency on `Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies`.

The lock file generated by 6.2 is compatible with 6.1.



### Verbose Logs

```shell
C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3>..\nuget-6.2.exe restore repro.csproj
MSBuild auto-detection: using msbuild version '17.2.1.25201' from 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Enterprise\MSBuild\Current\bin'.
Restoring packages for C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\repro.csproj...
NU1101: Unable to find package Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages, nuget.org
WARNING: NU1701: Package 'Microsoft.CrmSdk.Data 9.0.2.33' was restored using '.NETFramework,Version=v4.6.1, .NETFramework,Version=v4.6.2, .NETFramework,Version=v4.7, .NETFramework,Version=v4.7.1, .NETFramework,Version=v4.7.2, .NETFramework,Version=v4.8' instead of the project target framework 'net6.0'. This package may not be fully compatible with your project.
Generating MSBuild file C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\obj\repro.csproj.nuget.g.props.
Generating MSBuild file C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\obj\repro.csproj.nuget.g.targets.
Writing assets file to disk. Path: C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\obj\project.assets.json
Failed to restore C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\repro.csproj (in 583 ms).

Errors in C:\Users\user\Downloads\test3\repro.csproj
    NU1101: Unable to find package Microsoft.CrmSdk.CoreAssemblies. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages, nuget.org

NuGet Config files used:
    C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\NuGet\NuGet.Config
    C:\Program Files (x86)\NuGet\Config\Microsoft.VisualStudio.Offline.config

Feeds used:
    C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackages\
    https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json


C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\NuGet\NuGet.Config:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" protocolVersion="3" />
  </packageSources>
</configuration>

C:\Program Files (x86)\NuGet\Config\Microsoft.VisualStudio.Offline.config:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <add key="Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages" value="C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackages\"/>
  </packageSources>
</configuration>
```
